intro: Selinum multicaule, commonly known as the slender chervil, is a herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and is often found in moist, shady environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are aromatic and have been historically used in culinary and medicinal applications. However, it is important to note that some species within the genus Selinum can be toxic, so caution is advised when handling or consuming it.
